thread.title: The 1975, Mumford & Sons and Fleet Foxes for Latitude 2017
thread.title_full: The 1975, Mumford & Sons and Fleet Foxes for Latitude 2017

title: The 1975, Mumford & Sons and Fleet Foxes for Latitude 2017
text:
The 1975, Mumford & Sons and Fleet Foxes for Latitude 2017 01/03/17 
The 1975, Mumford & Sons and Fleet Foxes have been announced as the headliners for Latitude 2017. 
The likes of Jack Garrat, Lucy Rose and Fatboy Slim are also on the line-up for the festival at Henham Park in Suffolk between 13 and 16 July. 
Matty Healy from The 1975 told Newsbeat the booking, which will be among their first UK headline slots, is "a milestone" for the band. 
"Latitude could be the biggest moment of our careers." 
The four-piece will headline on the Friday night, with Mumford & Sons topping the bill on the Saturday evening in a UK exclusive set. 
They'll also be curating some of the main stage line-up that day as part of their Gentlemen of the Road tour. 
Fleet Foxes will close the festival on the Sunday night with another UK festival exclusive set. Image caption Emerging acts like Jorja Smith have also been announced on the line-up 
Temples, Kurupt FM and Loyal Carner also also among the names who have been confirmed on the line-up. 
They'll be joined by Maggie Rogers, The Japanese House, The Horrors and Jorja Smith who finished fourth on the BBC Sound of 2017 poll. 
Latitude has seen the bands like Foals and The Maccabees given their first UK headline slots before going on to do the same at other major festivals. 
Matty said he knows it's a good opportunity for the band. 
"I remember the Foals slot," he said. 
"I wouldn't call it a test but, it's almost like to see if you're ready to take on that headline slot. 
"We're going to try and rise to the challenge." Image caption Matty said their Latitude show will be a "massive version" of their current tour 
The announcement comes almost exactly a year after the release of The 1975's second album I Like It When You Sleep, For You Are So Beautiful Yet So Unaware of It. 
In that time it's been number one in both the UK and the US and was nominated for the Mercury Prize. Image caption The 1975 were name best British group at this year's Brit Awards 
"The album's kind of taken on a life of its own," said Matty. 
"It's been celebrated to the point where we're headlining Latitude - I'm just really humbled by that. 
"Latitude will be our swan song then we'll be back with a better record. 
"We're ending the era of I Like It When You Sleep and we're working on lots of future work. 
"I'm not going to rush anything - I'm just going to make a record. 
"We've only made records we love, so we'll just to that again."
